Award.AwardTitle: Optimization of Individualized Medical Treatment for Improved Population Health

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Chronic diseases are the leading cause of death in the United States, and diabetes in particular is one of the major underlying causes of stroke, coronary heart disease, kidney failure, and blindness. Despite extraordinary advances in the development of medications for treating chronic diseases like diabetes there are significant barriers to achieving their full benefits in practice. Existing treatment guidelines are often "one-size-fits-all" and do not account for the heterogeneous nature of patients. They are frequently focused on a single risk factor, while many chronic diseases have multiple risk factors that interact in a complex way. The goal of this project is to develop methods for measuring the benefits and the costs of treatment guidelines for chronic diseases, such as diabetes. Specifically, mathematical models will be created that can simulate the progression of chronic diseases over a patient's lifetime. Moreover, new algorithms will be designed that can be used to discover treatment guidelines that are optimized to account for individual patient risk factors, uncertainty health outcomes, and other factors influencing treatment decisions.

Formulation and validation of mathematical models for chronic disease progression requires the use of very large data sets with longitudinal population level data including laboratory, claims, and other data that makeup the complete electronic health record for a patient. Model parameter estimates are subject to unavoidable uncertainty as a result of patient heterogeneity, missing data, and conflicting estimates from different data sources. Additionally, complex interactions between disease risk factors, treatment efficacy, and medication adherence give rise to new large-scale optimization models that are difficult to solve. To address these challenges, this project will (a) create and validate new stochastic models for robust optimization of treatment guidelines that explicitly account for the heterogeneous nature of patients and their variation in adherence behavior; (b) analyze the mathematical structure of these models and develop methods for computing optimal treatment policies; (c) develop ways to integrate patient adherence behavior into treatment models; and (d) use insights from the optimal policies obtained to develop fast, easy-to-implement, near optimal guidelines, that account for individual patient preferences, and which can be implemented as an aid to clinicians and policy makers to improve population health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chronic diseases are the leading cause of death in the United States, and diabetes, in particular, is one of the major underlying causes of stroke, coronary heart disease, kidney failure, and blindness. Despite advances in the development of medications for treating chronic diseases like cardiovascular disease and diabetes, there are significant barriers to achieving their full benefits in practice. Existing treatment guidelines are often ‘‘one-size-fits-all’’ and do not account for the differences in patients. Moreover, they are frequently focused on a single risk factor, while many chronic diseases have multiple risk factors that interact to influence the health status of the patients. 

 The primary goal of this proposal was to develop data-driven mathemical models to improve decision making for the treatment of chronic diseases. The research team created new mathematical models and computational methods that use longitudinal medical record data to simulate the progression of chronic diseases over a patient’s lifetime. A key innovation of these models over past studies is that they account for the fact that medical studies provide conflicting information due to natural variaion in study designs, populations, and other factors. As a result, there is ambiguity in what constitutes the “right” model. Our approach deals with this ambiguity by accounting for the existence of multiple plausible models of how diseases progress and the risk of adverse events, such as arises regularly in many areas of medicine.

The newly developed models were analyzed to understand the influence that ambiguity in data inputs has on the resulting decisions that are recommended by the models. Further, algorithms for solving these new models were created, implemented, and tested to establish their potential for practical impact. Subsequently, these algorithms were used to find optimal policies for case studies in the areas of cardiovascular disease and diabetes as a proof of concepts and also to answer questions about the influence of ambiguity in clinical studies of these diseases. All of the methods created as part of this project can be applied to other contexts in which sequential decisions are made under conditions of uncertainty and model ambiguity such as finance, operations management, machine maintenance, and others. 

The project team was comprised of researchers with expertise in the fields of industrial engineering, medicine, and health services research. The research team also included several graduate students and undergraduate students who benefited from the opportunity to be involved in a multidisciplinary research experience. The discoveries from this project were reported in a series of journal articles and public presentations at univerities, and national and internatoinal conferences. Future opportunities for the study of the pervasive impact of ambiguity in data were identified. The results of this project have laid the foundation for these future studies.
